awd_titl_txt: Coastal SEES Collaborative Research: Climate change impacts on the sustainability of key fisheries of the California Current System
awd_abstract_narration:
The area off the California coast supports productive commercial and recreational fisheries such as squid, sardine, and lobster that are important to human cultures, economies, and livelihoods. Climate change is expected to alter the oceanic system and contribute to changes in fish populations that will directly affect fishers' profits and behavior, as well as managers' actions in setting limits on harvest. This collaborative Coastal SEES study brings together oceanographers, fisheries scientists, economists, and social scientists to develop a better understanding of interactions among the climate and coastal ocean system, fish populations, fishers and fishing communities, and resource management. The research team includes state and federal scientists, and results will be shared with the resource management community. The project will support interdisciplinary training for undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral scientists, and the investigators will participate in a number of public outreach activities. 

This Coastal SEES project assembles a diverse team of oceanographers, fisheries scientists, economists, and social scientists to develop new, integrated understanding of climate effects on coastal fisheries. The investigators will examine how fishing behavior, income, jobs distribution, and livelihood viability will be altered by climate change. The focus is on three key commercially harvested species that are known to respond to environmental change: Pacific sardine, California market squid, and California spiny lobster. Each of these supports an economically important fishery and represents a different type of organism in terms of marine habitat, latitudinal range, and time scale of response. The approach will include global climate model projections, regional ocean modeling, fisheries modeling, economics modeling, plus studies of management scenarios and fisher behavior. The goal will be to help develop sustainable management strategies under future climate scenarios given predicted ecological, social, and economic outcomes for these three fisheries.

inst.inst_name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

por.por_cntn:
The California Current System drives a vigorous coastal oceanic ecosystem that supports commercial and recreational fisheries that are important to cultures, economies, and livelihoods along the U.S. West Coast. Climate variability alters the physical-biological balances in the system and contributes to fish population changes that directly affect fishers? profits and behavior, as well as managers? actions in setting limits on harvest.

We studied key facets of the sustainability of the ecological-economic-societal interplay that results from climate changes in this ecosystem. As a diverse team of oceanographers, fisheries scientists, economists, and social scientists, we developed a multidisciplinary modeling procedure to estimate how climate-forced changes in the environment and fisheries will alter fishing behavior, income, jobs distribution, and livelihood viability. These interactions are schematized in the figure.

Our efforts included studying how three commercially harvested species (Pacific sardine, California market squid, and California spiny lobster) respond to physical-oceanographic climate change scenarios using climate models and regional ocean models. Based on the changes in stock size and range from those modeling results, we constructed economic models that predict spatial variability of jobs and income, viable fishing regions, mobility of fishers, economics of each target fishery, and wider economic effects on the region. We are also developed methods to test the sensitivity of these results to various management scenarios and fisher behavior.

We expect our products will yield practical information that can improve policy decision-making to yield benefits for society through fisheries management at NOAA and CDFW.

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2021
Modified by: Arthur J Miller

  • Schematic of our integrated research program: As climate change alters the coastalocean, we studied how changing fish populations affect profits and jobs, and howhuman reactions to the changes can enhance coastal sustainability through various policy scenarios.
